reg:regulation.reg:title: Public Health Act Transitional Regulation
reg:regulation.reg:amsincluded: [includes amendments up to B.C. Reg. 70/2012, March 31, 2012]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this regulation, Act means the Public Health Act.
A reference in a regulation made under the Health Act to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Health Act is to be read as a reference to the Act, and
a public health inspector or a sanitary inspector is to be read as a reference to an environmental health officer.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A regulation made under the Health Act continues to apply for the purposes of the Act, subject to any modifications, express or implied, made to it by the Act or this regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of applying the Health Act Communicable Disease Regulation, B.C. Reg. 4/83,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: except in section 18 of the regulation, communicable disease and infectious agent have the same meaning as in the Act,
all provisions of that regulation also apply to the communicable diseases
as if those communicable diseases had been prescribed as reportable communicable diseases under Schedule A of that regulation, and
all provisions of that regulation also apply to the organisms
as if those organisms had been prescribed as reportable communicable diseases under Schedule B of that regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are prescribed as infectious agents for the purposes of all sections of the Act, except section 17, that refer to an infectious agent or an infected person:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a reportable communicable disease within the meaning of the Health Act Communicable Disease Regulation, B.C. Reg. 4/83;
a communicable disease or organism listed in subsection (1) (b) or (c).

bcl:section.bcl:text: In addition to satisfying the requirements of the Environmental Management Act, a person who causes or permits the discharge into the land, water or air of a substance that is a health hazard must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: promptly notify a medical health officer in writing of the matters set out in section 11 of the Act, as well as the time, duration and quantity of the discharge of the substance, and
take immediate action to mitigate and cease the discharge.

section.marginalnote: No fee for use of public toilet

subsection.subsectiontext: In this section, public toilet means a toilet that is located in a place to which the public has access, whether or not a fee is charged for that access, but does not include a toilet that is located in a private dwelling.
A person who owns, occupies or has control of a place other than a private dwelling must not

paragraph.paragraphtext: demand or require payment for the use of a public toilet, or
have control of, or permit a person to install, a public toilet that operates or is accessible only on payment.

subsection.subsectiontext: A person who contravenes subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $2Â 000.

subsection.subsectiontext: A landlord must not rent a rental unit that is not connected to a waterworks system unless the landlord can provide the tenant with a supply of safe and potable water for domestic purposes.

section.marginalnote: Distance of wells from possible source of contamination

subsection.subsectiontext: A person who sinks or digs a well after section 42 of the Sanitary Regulations, B.C. Reg. 142/59, was first enacted must ensure that the well is located at least

paragraph.paragraphtext: 100 feet from any probable source of contamination,
20 feet from any private dwelling, and
unless contamination of the well would be impossible because of the physical conformation, 400 feet from any cemetery or dumping ground.

subsection.subsectiontext: A person who controls a well sunk or dug before section 42 of the Sanitary Regulations was first enacted must

paragraph.paragraphtext: remove any source of contamination within the distances set out in subsection (1), or
subject to subsection (3), abandon and fill the well.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subsection (2) (b) does not apply to a well located within 20 feet of a private dwelling unless it can be shown that the well should be abandoned for a reason other than proximity to a private dwelling.
